so let's pretend I'm a late adoptor here

from the outside looking in when you
look at companies that do spectacular
things it always looks like a big bang
it always looks like they uh they had
one at bat and they swung and they at
that home run what really great
companies do is they fail a lot but they
make those failures really invisible but
really what they've done what they'
really what they've mastered and I think
this is the critical skill is they've
mastered lowering the cost of failure
and that's really it right because the
problem is these big great ideas um the
the you know the Amazon primes and you

services that you know each of us use
and each of us know about that you know

cases even more of uh very small
failures so you need to be experimenting
all the time but the problem is if the
uh cost of failure is what it is in a
data center for example then it's very
hard to afford those those failures so
you can do very few of them maybe none
um and so that's why I I say that
reducing the cost of failure is the key
to those big successes because it's not
about having the smartest people of
course that helps it's not about coming
up with the best ideas of course that
helps but what it's really about it's
about iterating as much as possible and
being able to fail as quickly as
inexpensively as possible so that when
you finally hit that home run when you
finally get that great idea that just
just works that you can really double
down and invest in that and then show
